conclusion: Identify the net direction of energy exchange to decide heat absorption or release.
Net heat absorbed in the cycle equals net work done by the gas in the cycle.
If the curve on the p-V diagram is traversed counter-clockwise, the gas does negative work and net heat is rejected.
If the curve is traversed clockwise, the gas does positive work and net heat is absorbed.
Path a → b is isochoric with increasing pressure.
Path b → c is adiabatic with increasing volume and decreasing pressure.
Path c → d is isochoric with decreasing pressure.
Path d → a is adiabatic with decreasing volume and increasing pressure.
The sequence encloses the cycle in a counter-clockwise sense, resulting in negative work done by the gas.
Work done by the gas is less than zero, implying net heat added to the gas is less than zero.
Magnitude of heat released is greater than the magnitude of heat absorbed.
Final answer: During one complete cycle the gas rejects more heat than it absorbs.
